newsitem.title: UK: TENNIS-MOYA GIVES SPAIN DAVIS CUP VICTORY OVER GERMANY.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-MOYA GIVES SPAIN DAVIS CUP VICTORY OVER GERMANY.

text.p: Australian Open finalist Carlos Moya cruised to a straight-sets victory over Hendrik Dreekman on Sunday to give Spain an unbeatable 3-1 lead over 1993 champions Germany in their Davis Cup world group first round match.
Moya broke Dreekman's serve in the opening games of the first two sets to win 6-4 6-4 7-5 on clay in Mallorca.

Jim Courier overcame a spirited challenge from Gustavo Kuerten to give 1995 champions United States a decisive 3-1 lead over Brazil in Ribeirao, winning 6-3 6-2 5-7 7-6. Alex O'Brien won the final singles against Fernando Meligeni.
Kuerten, ranked 60 places below Courier, saved four match points in the fourth set when the American twice volleyed into the net.
But Courier, who needed treatment for dehydration afterwards, held on to wrap up an awkward tie against a team who had not been beaten at home for 10 years.
Courier later made light of the noisy crowd, an informal samba band and a light aircraft which zoomed low over the arena during the first set.
"The crowd are very supportive of their team," he said
"I like the drum section, the horns are a bit much, a bit loud on the ears, but my favourite was the guy who flew the plane over the court. I'd like to meet him."
Sweden, runners-up to France in last year's final and now without the retired Stefan Edberg, crushed Switzerland 4-1 in Lulea, Sweden, to book a quarter-final against South Africa in April.
Thomas Enqvist clinched the rubber with a 6-3 6-2 3-6 6-2 win over Marc Rosset who was clearly feeling the effects of 10 hard sets over the previous two days.
"We are eager to bring the Cup to Sweden," said team captain Carl-Axel Hageskog. "With the team spirit and the very good players I have, I think it's possible. We have to go for it."
France were ousted from the Cup on Saturday by Australia, who completed the formality of a 4-1 win on Sunday.
The Netherlands, trailing 2-0 after the opening singles, completed a remarkable comeback by beating Romania in Bucharest.
Paul Haarhuis clinched the tie by beating Andrei Pavel 6-3 6-1 6-2 after team mate Jan Siemerink defeated Adrian Voinea 7-6 5-7 6-7 7-6 6-4.
"It was like winning the lottery," Siemerink remarked.

In Durban, South African doubles pair Ellis Ferreira and Grant Stafford defeated Russia's Andrei Olhovsky and Andrei Cherkasov 6-2 3-6 6-0 6-2 in a match carried over from Saturday to secure their quarter-final spot.
"We were expected to win but the first three matches were all tough," said South African captain Danie Visser. "This victory is very satisfying."
Jiri Novak sealed a 3-2 victory for the Czech Republic over India with an easy 6-1 6-4 6-3 after the Czech number one Petr Korda had levelled the tie in his final Davis Cup appearance.
Korda defeated Leander Paes 5-7 6-3 6-4 6-1 then announced he was retiring from Davis Cup tennis.
"It is a very tiring, draining experience and I think you should leave at the top," Korda said. "Now is the right time."
